message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Conn syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, involves the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal gland, which produces aldosterone. Pheochromocytomas, on the other hand, involve the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla, which produce catecholamines such as adrenaline and noradrenaline. Therefore, the correct answer is B, which indicates that Conn syndrome involves the zona glomerulosa and pheochromocytomas involve the adrenal medulla.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Conn syndrome is caused by a tumor in the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal gland, which results in excess production of aldosterone, leading to hypertension. Pheochromocytoma is caused by a tumor in the medulla of the adrenal gland, which results in excess production of catecholamines, leading to hypertension.

Pheochromocytomas, on the other hand, affect the medulla of the adrenal gland, which produces catecholamines like epinephrine and norepinephrine. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) - zona glomerulosa for Conn syndrome and medulla for pheochromocytomas.

Conn syndrome is caused by an adenoma or hyperplasia of the zona glomerulosa, leading to excess production of aldosterone, while pheochromocytomas arise from chromaffin cells in the medulla, leading to excess production of catecholamines. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer, as it correctly identifies the zones involved in each condition.
